text: All right.

I think we have almost everybody
in from the waiting room.

So welcome, Section G,
to your diploma ceremony,

where we celebrate each
and every one of you

receiving your diploma from
Harvard Business School.
It has a nice ring to it, right?

You are henceforth
graduates of HBS.

This also means a somewhat
more poignant moment
that we are marking today.

This is the very last time that
you will gather as students.

Every future
gathering, and I have

no doubt there will be many,
you will be gathering together
as alumni.

I am so happy and honored
to share this moment

with you and with your partners,
friends, families, mentors,

babies, and loved
ones joining us

by livestream, whose
love and support

has been such an important
part of bringing Section

G to and through
these last two years.

For those of you
who I haven't met,

welcome and thank you
so much for joining us.

My name is Emily
McComb, and I have

had the privilege of teaching
this amazing group of students.

So that transition
from student to alumni,

what is the path that has
been taken to get there?

For the friends,
family, and mentors

gathered with us, and for a walk
down memory lane for Section G,

get a little sense of what
these students have been through
together.

Let's go back for a
moment to August 28, 2019.

The very first day of HBS
begins with all 938 students

of the class of 2021
gathered for the opening
welcome and the dean's address.

They were the first class
to congregate entirely

in the brand new and quite
beautiful Klarman Hall.

We didn't know it at the
time, but it was only one

of many firsts for this
extraordinary class,

because they certainly
have witnessed
their fair share of firsts.

In Klarman Hall, there was
a sort of excited, slightly
nervous energy.

You can feel sort of a
palpable anticipation.

What is this place
going to be like?
I can't believe I'm here.

Everyone keeps telling
me that I am embarking

on a transformational
experience,
and what does that even mean?

Who are all these people and
who will be in my section?

That question is answered
with a big reveal--
yes, I am in Section G.

Students then move
to their classroom

for the very first
time together,

the room that will be home
base for the whole first year.

What was a massive
gathering of 938

becomes a section of just
93, and those 93 people

become for each other such
an important part of the HBS
journey.

For example, in this
classroom, with this section

in that first year, Section G
completed more than 250 case

studies and spent literally
hundreds of hours learning
together and from one another.

And that learning takes
on many different forms--

sometimes debating,
often laughing,
and yes, sometimes even tears.

But the classroom is only one
aspect of learning at HBS,

and there is a lot of learning
that happens outside as well.

HBS can be both exhilarating
and completely overwhelming.

It feels like there aren't
possibly enough hours

in the day to do everything that
is offered, and there aren't.

There are speakers and club
events, sports, dinners,

coffees, recruiting,
and an endless number
of social invitations.

Sometimes you have to
say no, and that's hard.

When you've been drinking
from an HBS firehose,

sometimes things as mundane as
sleep need to be prioritized,
and that's hard.

Sometimes, even often, there is
FOMO, or fear of missing out,
and that's hard.

A week can feel like both a
minute and a lifetime at once.

This group helped each other
out, gave each other advice,

give each other a hug
when it was needed.

I got to teach you, Section
G, in your second semester.

I remember clearly it was
9:10 AM on Monday, January 27,

when I first walked into
Aldrich 008 for our first class
of FIN2.

It was our first
of many cases that

included Warren Buffett, who is
a recurring character in FIN2.

Now, for those of
you who don't know,

a great case
discussion is a skill
that is definitely learned.

It's a skill that takes
patience to build,

and it involves the group
being able to truly listen

to classmates, to be
open to new viewpoints,

to maybe even
changing their mind.

This is a group that
had an uncanny ability

to do all of these things
extraordinarily well.

They were willing to take
risks, to try something new,

to ask probing questions, and
they trusted each other enough

to maybe even sometimes,
gasp, be wrong.

In short, they were
a joy to teach.

And so our semester started
apace, blissfully unaware

of the scale of what
was coming at us.

We had parents and friends and
partners visit our classroom.

We could stand up
and cheer, unmasked,

at the brilliant
comments that were made.

Mae's mom got cold-called
and nailed it.

There was an errant cockroach
that was gallantly slain.

And then things
started to change.

I remember very clearly
having lunch with 10 of you

on March 3, 2020,
and we were talking

about bending the curve,
social distancing, PPE.

These were things that
were new to our vocabulary.

But we also talked
about spring break

and the plans that were
set and the plans that
were starting to be broken.

Less than three weeks
later, we were 100% Zoom.

I had lunch with another 10 of
you, but virtually this time,

and we were talking about fear
and worry, a ravaged stock

market, uncertainty about
what was coming next.
But Section G kept going.

Collectively, they
held each other up.

This was before Zoom
had a convenient option

to blur the background,
and we witnessed
all sorts of messy apartments.

Before the notion to mute and
unmute became second nature.

"Can you hear me" and "still
me" were still new phrases.

This was before HBS had a
chance to acquire all the latest

and greatest equipment, so
I was free-handing charts

in a closet in New Hampshire
that looked absolutely nothing
like they were supposed to.

And yet, this group
always had a smile.

Despite all the
worry-- and there

was a lot-- and the hardship,
and an HBS experience that

didn't look anything
like they had expected,

they persevered and made it
the best possible experience
that it could be.

Section G, I admire your
strength and everything

that you have accomplished in
these extraordinary last two
years.

Now, at the end of
the semester, there

is normally a roast
of the professor.

And as the instructor,
one must steel oneself

for a spot-on
impersonation of the things

that you like least
about yourself.

But not Section G. You were
so kind and generous that you
made me cry.
So now it's my turn.
I wrote you a poem--

"Oh, the Places You'll
Go," by Dr. Seuss,
and as amended by me.

Congratulations,
today is your day.
You're off to great places.
Section G is off and away.

You have brains in your head,
your feet in your shoes,

with your HBS degree, you'll
go wherever you choose.

Your options are endless
outside the bubble of Boston,

be it Bain, Goldman, or Google,
or a search fund in London.

You'll make a
difference in the world,

no doubt great
things will get done.

You'll inspire
organizations, you'll
never be poor, [INAUDIBLE].

And when you choose
to change tracks,

you'll consider
options with care.

About some you will say, I
don't choose to go there.

With your head full of brains
and your shoes full of feet,

you're too smart to go down
any not-so-good street.

But if you do, and
sometimes you might,

the future might
every now and again
look somewhat less bright.

In those moments you'll think
of a case, a comment, a laugh.

You might wistfully remember
a late Friday's [INAUDIBLE]..

The pain of previous days
will long be forgotten.

Emails of no new guidance a
thing of the distant past.

You'll just think fondly of
those friends you met in 2019,

and realize they're
friendships that last.

These are friends you can
call for support and a giggle.

These are friends you can
call for advice to be told.

These friends that only
two years ago felt new

have graduated to the forever
status of friends that are old.

Together, you will have
been through so much,

and together, you
have rocked it.

Through cases, parties,
business plans, and Zoom,

Section G made it great,
even through COVID.

For me, my words of advice are
to always listen and to never
shy away from doing the numbers.

Remember, everything
is a negotiation,

and it all comes back
to Butler Lumber.

Always keep the sense
of childish wonder,

reflect on your goals, and
what you want to achieve.

And will, Section
G, will you succeed?
99.99999% guaranteed.

So be your name Jenna or Justin
or Mae, Joshua, Alex, Kevin,

Lauren, or Shrey or
Jamal, [? Fines ?] Kam
or Megan Murday.

All of Section G is
off to great places.
Today is your day.
Your mountain is waiting.
So get on your way.

Section G, I hope
that you continue

to draw inspiration and
strength from each other,

and whatever your
path, I wish all

of you happiness and
health and success,

in whatever form
that means to you.
So enough from me.

We will now transition
to giving you

your diplomas, when we recognize
each and every one of you.

First, I'd like to
share a few minutes

from the chair of the MBA
program, Jan Rivkin, explaining

the meaning of the honors and
the titles that are conferred.

Congratulations again
to the class of 2021.

You are now officially
HBS graduates.

You know, graduation day is
my favorite day of the year.

I love seeing our
students so happy.

I love seeing their
families and friends

so rightly proud of their
graduates and so excited
about their bright futures.

And we now come to
my favorite part

of my favorite day of the
year-- the diploma ceremony,

where we recognize each and
every member of your section.

As members of the class
of 2021 are recognized,

you'll hear mentioned
three kinds of honors.
The first is distinction.

This is for students who
earned academic honors

in both the first year and the
second year of our program.
The second is high distinction.

These individuals not
only earned honors

in the first year
and the second year,

they also had a combined
academic performance

that placed them in the top
5% of their class as a whole.

These students were also known
as George F. Baker Scholars,

commemorating the individual
whose generosity in the 1920s
allowed us to build the campus.

I invite you to look
at the Baker Scholars

page on the graduation
website to learn more

about the legacy of George
Baker and this particular
distinction.

Third and last, but by no
means least, the Dean's Award.

The Dean's Award celebrates
the extraordinary achievements

of graduating students who,
during their time at HBS,

made distinctive contributions
to Harvard, to Harvard Business

School, or the
broader community.

These students have contributed
to the well-being of others

through amazing
acts of leadership.

Students and all
members of the community

nominate these individuals,
and then Dean Datar
makes the final selection.

So please enjoy the
diploma ceremony.

Celebrate each and every
member of your section.

I hope that your section will
remain close through the years,

as mine has, and I hope
that these two years at HBS

will be just the beginning of an
ongoing conversation among you,

as you enjoy long, happy
years of making differences

that are meaningful to you
and meaningful for the world.
Be well and stay close.

All right, so now at long last,
the actual diploma ceremony.

I hope that some of the
bright side of being on Zoom

is that you can be in
shorts and flip-flops
and those black robes.

So with that, let's
start the show.

Congratulations to you all.
Cheers.

Congratulations.

And now we turn our attention
to the many supporters

who have helped to
make this happen.

To families, friends, mentors,
partners, role models,

and loved ones,
your graduates were

asked to contribute photos
to recognize the support that

has meant so much
to the HBS journey,

whether long before
the journey began

in planning the run-up
to these last two years,

or the gratitude for
knowing your encouragement

will be there as these graduates
make their way into the world.

I've heard so many times
from so many of Section G

how incredibly
grateful they have been

and just how much they missed
families and friends back home,

whether that was in Newton
or on another continent, how

grateful they've been for
partners that trek to Boston
or stayed long distance--
[CHEERING]

--calls at all sorts of
hours in order to catch up.

Families, friends,
mentors, and partners, HBS

is a huge journey, and yes,
it is a transformational one.
And now--

Make no mistake that your love,
your support, your advice,

and just being you and
providing a rock of stability

has been a huge part of
these graduates' success.

This next video is celebrating
all of that support,

and it is a beautiful
and fitting way

to close our diploma ceremony
because we know just how

much that support
has contributed
to the success of these grads.

To conclude your
diploma ceremony,

let's end with a fitting
celebration of your loved ones.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
I love that.

Thank you, families,
friends, partners, mentors,

loved ones for
everything you've done

to help make this experience
possible for our grads.

So with that, Section G, I wish
you a safe and the happiest
of celebrations.

I cannot wait to see your
future accomplishments,

and I hope one day to be able
to celebrate with you in close
personal proximity.

But until then, I'm
always here for you.

I would love to see you if
you're ever back on campus
and hear from you.

Thank you for letting me
be here for this moment.
Congratulations, Section G.
